title: ctELM: Decoding and Manipulating Embeddings of Clinical Trials with Embedding Language Models
summary: This paper introduces ctELM, an Embedding Language Model (ELM) designed to decode and manipulate embeddings of clinical trials. ctELM enables accurate description and comparison of unseen clinical trials from their embeddings and can generate plausible trial abstracts, demonstrating responsiveness to specific semantic concept vectors like age and sex. The work addresses the limited interpretability and generative capabilities of traditional text embeddings, offering a new tool for biomedical language applications.

title: MortalMATH: Evaluating the Conflict Between Reasoning Objectives and Emergency Contexts
summary: This paper introduces MortalMATH, a benchmark evaluating Large Language Models' (LLMs) ability to prioritize safety over task completion in critical situations. It reveals that while generalist models appropriately address life-threatening emergencies described alongside algebra requests, specialized reasoning models frequently ignore the danger, maintain high math task completion rates, and introduce dangerous delays. The study suggests that deep reasoning optimization may inadvertently compromise crucial safety instincts in LLMs.

title: HalluGuard: Demystifying Data-Driven and Reasoning-Driven Hallucinations in LLMs
summary: This paper introduces HalluGuard, a novel theoretical framework and practical method to address critical LLM hallucinations stemming from both data-driven and reasoning-driven sources. It formalizes hallucination risk using the Hallucination Risk Bound and proposes an NTK-based score to jointly detect these issues. HalluGuard consistently achieves state-of-the-art performance across diverse LLMs and benchmarks, significantly enhancing LLM reliability.

title: Conditioned Generative Modeling of Molecular Glues: A Realistic AI Approach for Synthesizable Drug-like Molecules
summary: This paper introduces a novel AI-assisted drug design method using a Ligase-Conditioned Junction Tree Variational Autoencoder (LC-JT-VAE) to generate E3 ligase-specific molecular glues. These generated molecules are designed to promote the targeted degradation of intracellular amyloid beta-42 (Abeta-42), a key pathological driver in Alzheimer's disease, via the ubiquitin-proteasome system.

title: Analyzing Images of Blood Cells with Quantum Machine Learning Methods: Equilibrium Propagation and Variational Quantum Circuits to Detect Acute Myeloid Leukemia
summary: This feasibility study demonstrates that quantum machine learning (QML) algorithms, specifically Equilibrium Propagation (EP) and Variational Quantum Circuits (VQCs), can achieve competitive performance for automated Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) detection from blood cell microscopy images. Despite severe constraints like classical simulation and reduced image resolution, QML methods attained 83.0-86.4% accuracy, only 12-15% below classical CNNs, with VQCs showing significant data efficiency.

title: Health-SCORE: Towards Scalable Rubrics for Improving Health-LLMs
summary: Health-SCORE introduces a novel framework for scalable rubric-based evaluation and training of Large Language Models (LLMs) in safety-critical healthcare domains, significantly reducing the cost and time typically required for human expert rubric development. It achieves evaluation quality comparable to human-created rubrics, enhancing the efficiency and safety of LLM deployment by serving as a structured reward signal for reinforcement learning and improving responses via in-context learning.

title: Chemotaxis-inspired PDE models of airborne infectious disease transmission: epidemiologically-motivated mathematical and numerical analyses
summary: This paper advances PDE models for airborne infectious diseases by integrating a chemotaxis-type term, which accounts for disease propagation towards higher susceptible populations, addressing limitations of traditional reaction-diffusion models. It introduces an epidemiologically interpretable framework, including a novel spatially-aware basic reproduction number, and demonstrates significantly improved capture of spatiotemporal disease dynamics in real-world simulations compared to pure reaction-diffusion models. This provides a more accurate tool for policymakers to understand and manage outbreaks.

title: Learning temporal embeddings from electronic health records of chronic kidney disease patients
summary: This paper investigates the ability of temporal embedding models, specifically recurrent neural networks, to learn clinically meaningful and task-agnostic representations from longitudinal electronic health records of chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients. It demonstrates that the Time-aware LSTM (T-LSTM) produces superior, more structured embeddings for CKD stage classification. Furthermore, learning embeddings as an intermediate step consistently outperforms direct end-to-end prediction for in-ICU mortality, indicating a more effective approach for clinical predictive tasks.

title: Contrasting Global and Patient-Specific Regression Models via a Neural Network Representation
summary: This paper introduces a diagnostic tool designed to contrast global clinical prediction models with patient-specific (local) models, aiming to identify where and for whom a global model may be inadequate. The approach utilizes localized regression in a dimension-reduced latent space derived from an autoencoder, enabling the identification and characterization of patient subgroups whose outcomes deviate from the global model. Applied to a COPD study, it revealed that while a global model sufficed for most, specific subgroups indeed benefited from personalized models.

title: TwinPurify: Purifying gene expression data to reveal tumor-intrinsic transcriptional programs via self-supervised learning
summary: TwinPurify is a novel self-supervised learning framework designed to extract tumor-intrinsic transcriptional programs from bulk gene expression data. It addresses the challenge of tumor purity variation, which often obscures true tumor signals, by leveraging adjacent-normal profiles as guidance. This method purifies bulk transcriptomics, leading to improved molecular classification, enhanced survival prediction, and discovery of biologically meaningful pathways, thereby extending the utility of existing clinical datasets.

title: From Cold Start to Active Learning: Embedding-Based Scan Selection for Medical Image Segmentation
summary: This paper introduces a novel active learning framework for medical image segmentation, addressing the critical bottleneck of manual annotation. It proposes an embedding-based cold-start strategy using foundation models and clustering for diverse initial training, followed by an uncertainty and spatial diversity-guided sample selection. The method consistently improves segmentation accuracy, as measured by Dice coefficient and Hausdorff distance, over baseline methods across various X-ray and MRI datasets, particularly in low-data regimes.
